subtitles.transcript: Grant and scholarship aid, so this is not loans,
but grant and scholarship aid has risen dramatically during these tuition increases
and in fact, the university has reserved a lot of the tuition increases –
about a third of the tuition increases – to provide grant scholarship aid.
California’s Cal Grant program has risen to match tuition increases at UC and CSU
so that students from low-income and even middle-income families
have not had to pay these tuition increases
and still this accessibility in terms of having very low or no tuition for low-income students
and I’m often frustrated when I see a headline that says “UC going to raise tuition”
and then the article does not include the fact that at the same time,
institutional grant aid is being increased so that at least from a tuition standpoint,
low-income students don’t have to pay that tuition
and I think it creates this misperception among many Californians
that UC is unaffordable for low-income students
and it’s certainly a challenge for anybody because there are other costs besides tuition,
but from a tuition standpoint, it’s not unaffordable at all.
